arm_group.description: Subjects will be recruited from the University of Wisconsin-Madison course, "Introduction to Martial Arts: Tai Chi".
Subjects will be recruited from the University of Wisconsin-Madison course "Introduction to Psychology".

brief_summary.textblock:
The general purpose of this study is to examine the effect of tai chi training on cognitive
      function in young adults. The investigators will test subjects enrolled in a semester-long
      tai chi course along with control subjects. The specific aims are to measure duration of
      practice, cognitive function, physical balance, and Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder
      (ADHD) indicators. The investigators primary hypotheses are that, compared to controls,
      subjects in the tai chi course will show improvements in (1a) spatial working memory and
      (1b) response inhibition. The investigators secondary hypotheses are that, among the
      subjects participating in the tai chi course, these cognitive improvements will correlate
      with (2a) improvements in balance and (2b) duration of tai chi practice, and that, among all
      participants, (2c) ADHD indications will correlate with cognitive measures.

clinical_study.brief_title: Psychological Effects of Tai Chi Training

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  Able to perform balance and cognitive tests

        Exclusion Criteria:

intervention.description: 24 form Yang style Tai Chi. 50 minute sessions, twice weekly.

clinical_study.official_title: Psychological Effects of Tai Chi Training

primary_outcome.description: CANTAB Spatial Working Memory Task: SWM between errors

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

secondary_outcome.description: One Legged Stance Test. Time standing on one leg with eyes closed. Average over left and right leg of best of three trials on each side.
CANTAB Stop Signal Task: reaction time (SSRT).
CANTAB Affective Go/No-Go Task: mean correct latency
World Health Organization adult ADHD self-report scale (ASRS). Scoring of 6 item ASRS screener per Kessler et al. Psychological Medicine (2005) 35:245-256.
secondary_outcome.measure: Change in attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) scale

secondary_outcome.description: Total minutes of tai chi practice including class time.

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Non-Randomized, Intervention Model: Parallel Assignment, Masking: Open Label, Primary Purpose: Basic Science
